items.message:
River levels have risen at the Whitewater Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening, 20/09/23.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads around Mansfield, the Sherwood Forest Caravan Park at Clipstone, Edwinstowe, Ollerton, Whitewater Lane at Whitewater Bridge and West Drayton.   
We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21/09/23, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising on the Cole and Dorcan Brook as a result of heavy rainfall this morning. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected later this afternoon, 20 September 2023, especially in the Lower Stratton area. This morning's rainfall should clear this afternoon, leaving mainly dry conditions overnight. Scattered showers are possible in the area throughout tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising over the next few hours, but should then begin to fall later this afternoon. 

Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21 September 2023, or as the situation changes.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water following the recent heavy rainfall.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Areas most at risk include The Upper Derwent from Seathwaite to Derwent Water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are remaining high on the River Greta, River Derwent, Derwent Water lake level.
Flooding is affecting low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the evening.
River levels are remaining high at the Lodore gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall this afternoon as rainfall eases. 

We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.

Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
Flooding is possible at Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith, and South Esplanade from 05:00 AM on 21/09/2023.

Showers will continue to fall during Wednesday, before clearing into Thursday. Further showers are expected into the weekend, which may keep river levels high for a few days. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
No property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No property flooding is expected.
River levels are now falling steadily this evening 20/09/2023.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

This Flood Alert has now been removed. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on riverside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

The risk of flooding in the River Rase and Upper Ancholme Catchment Area has now reduced, and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days and we will continue to monitor the situation.

Tidal conditions have now fallen below levels of concern in Bridlington
After this tideâ€š the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected for the next few days

River levels are forecast to rise at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin between 14:00 and 16:00 today, 20/09/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.3m to 3.5m this evening; 
We expect river levels to remain high overnight. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.    
Please avoid contact with flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 tomorrow 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels have fallen below the flood alert level in this area.  
There may still be standing water and river levels may still be high.
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels are expected to remain high on the Rivers Lowther and Eamont.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Eamont and Lowther to their confluence with the River Eden at Langwathby.
Further showery rain is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are remaining high on the Rivers Kent and Bela.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.
Further showery rain is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are remaining high on the Rivers Caldew and Petteril.
Areas most at risk include Rivers Caldew and Petteril from the Lakeland Fells to Carlisle including Greystoke, Newton Reigny, Plumpton, Stockdalewath, Sebergham and Denton Holme in Carlisle.
River levels are expected to remain high at the Cummersdale; Denton Holme; Harraby Green Business Park; Melbourne Park; Newbiggin Bridge; Sebergham; Skew Bridge; Stockdalewath gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Hay-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin between 14:00 and 16:00 today, 20/09/2023.  
We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. 
Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 2.2m to 2.5m this evening, 
Bredwardine 4.0m to 4.2m overnight, 
Belmont 4.0m to 4.2m overnight, 
Old Wye Bridge 3.5m to 3.8m tomorrow morning, 
Ross on Wye 3.2m to .5m tomorrow afternoon.   
We expect river levels to remain high until tommorow night. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 tomorrow, 21/09/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high on the Middle River Eden.
Areas most at risk include River Eden and tributaries from Temple Sowerby to the confluence with the River Irthing at Warwick Bridge including Langwathby, Lazonby, Kirkoswald, Armathwaite, Wetheral and Warwick on Eden.
River levels are expected to remain high at the Eden Valley Flows; Great Corby;  gauge.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen this afternoon as rainfall eased and we expect them to continue to fall. There is still a chance that heavy showers this evening could have localised impacts. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

River levels have risen on the Upper River Eden due to recent heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include River Eden and other watercourses, from Kirkby Stephen to Temple Sowerby including low lying areas around Brough, Warcop, Great Ormside and Appleby.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses avoid walking or driving through flood water.

River levels are high on the Lower River Eden due to recent heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the River Eden and its tributaries from its confluence with the River Irthing through Crosby-on-Eden and Carlisle to the Solway Firth at Rockcliffe.

items.description: River Eden at Carlisle, Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses
items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Eden due to recent heavy rainfall.
Flooding is expected at low lying roads, car parks, public spaces and recreational facilities at Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses from 6:00pm on 20/09/2023. River levels are expected to reach 3.5m and remain at this level for several hours.
Further showers are forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Eden, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around farms and residential properties in the Warwick Holmes area.
Flooding is forecast to affect farms and residential properties in the Warwick Holmes area from 6:00pm on 20/09/2023. River levels are expected to reach 3.5m and remain at this level for several hours.
Further showery rain is forecast throughout the evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00am on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Ringwood Old Cottage river gauge as a result of persistent heavy rainfall impacting the New Forest Streams.  We expect flooding to affect tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch but particularly in the fords and crossings in the New Forest. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
There will be continued bands of rain until 10PM today the 20th September.
We are closely monitoring the situation and levels in the New Forest Streams
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated Tomorrow, 21st September, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected to begin overnight tonight, 20/09/2023.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. 
Predicted Peaks:- Ross on Wye 3.5m to 3.7m tomorrow afternoon , Lydbrook 4.0m to 4.2m tomorrow evening.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 

River levels are rising on the Bear Brook and tributaries as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected this evening, 20 September 2023, especially in the Aylesbury area. Some further rainfall is forecast this evening which will clear, leaving mainly dry conditions overnight. Scattered showers are possible in the area throughout tomorrow. We expect river levels to continue rising over the next few hours. 

Our staff are in the area clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 21 September 2023, or as the situation changes.

The water level in the Monks Brook is high and rising. In the last 4 hours, 21mm of rainfall has been recorded in Portswood. From 9.30pm this evening, 20/09/2023, the river will rise to bank full. It will be deep and fast flowing. The recreational ground at Fleming Park will experience flooding, and the river will be very high at Kingfisher Road. Surface water flooding in roads affecting Chandlers Ford and at Stoneham Way from Chestnut Way to the M27 is also possible. The heaviest rain has now cleared the area. Levels will remain high for the next 1 to 2 hours but should begin to fall by midnight on 20/09/2023. Property flooding is not currently expected. Our operational staff will keep the river free of reported blockages in Chandlers Ford and Eastleigh. We continue to monitor the forecast. Residents should remain vigilant, especially in Chandlers Ford, where culverts and debris screens in the river can block quickly. Please report blockages to our incident hotline on 0800 807060. This Flood Alert will be updated at 10.00am on 21/09/2023.

The water level in the River Blackwater at Ower and Cadnam River is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, more than half a monthâ€™s rain (41mm) has been recorded in Romsey. From 8:30am this morning (21/09/2023), the river will flood land, fields and roads at Cadnam, West Wellow, Landford and Ower. Water levels will also be very high around the mill building at East Wellow. Further showers are forecast throughout the day. We expect the river will rise at least until 10.00am on 21/09/2023. Although water levels will be much higher than normal, property flooding is not currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. Our operations staff will work to ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. Please ensure that pumps used to protect property are operating correctly. This Flood Alert will be updated by 12:00 on 21/09/2023.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

items.message:
River levels have risen on the River Dee due to rainfall.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Dee, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington.

River levels are expected to remain high on 21/09/2023.We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 7:00 PM on 21/09/2023, or as the situation changes.
